body: @bdpedigo just one doubt how to find out which version of matplotlib are incompatible?

just make sure it passes all of our tests with that version of matplotlib installed. i think the answer will be that 3.3.1 is the only bad one. 

also, im not sure, but you might have to look at whether seaborn version matters too. you can look at the original issue in seaborn that i linked in that PR.

issue.title: remove MPL version upper bound when bug gets fixed
issue.body: #402 is a hack, whenever that issue between seaborn/matplotlib gets fixed let's figure out which versions of both to allow

issue.title: Fix matplotlib version requirement
issue.body:
currently we have `matplotlib>=3.0.0,<=3.3.0`.
Matplotlib >= 3.4.0 has some nice features, like `supxtitle`.

Is there a reason we still clip the version?
If not, see #810

issue.title: fix matplotlib version
issue.body:
See #809.
Ignore if there's a good reason for clipping the version.

issue.title: Parallelize MASE initial embeddings
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at
the contribution guidelines: https://github.com/microsoft/graspologic/blob/dev/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

- [ ] Does this PR add any new dependencies?
- [ ] Does this PR modify any existing APIs?
   - [ ] Is the change to the API backwards compatible?
- [ ] Have you built the documentation (reference and/or tutorial) and verified the generated documentation is appropriate?

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.
Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
Closes #751 

#### What does this implement/fix? Briefly explain your changes.
 This commit is intended to make the SVD code faster. In the initial embedding step  prior to concatenation, MASE just does all the embeddings in a for-loop. This can be parallelized pretty easily with joblib library.

#### Any other comments?

body: Hi, I would like to work on this issue. Please guide me further on what needs to be done. Thanks😄

we just need someone to go through each version of matplotlib since 3.3.0, install that version of the package, run our tests, and document whether or not all tests pass with that version of matplotlib installed
bump, would like to prioritize this, we should allow `matplotlib 3.4.3`, there are some good new features and it's making incompatibility bugs pop up

issue.title: Update matplotlib version specification to allow >=3.4.*
issue.body:
- [ ] Does this PR add any new dependencies?
- [ ] Does this PR modify any existing APIs?
   - [ ] Is the change to the API backwards compatible?
- [ ] Have you built the documentation (reference and/or tutorial) and verified the generated documentation is appropriate?

#### Reference Issues/PRs
#726 

#### What does this implement/fix? Briefly explain your changes.
Updates the version spec to allow most recent versions of matplotlib

#### Any other comments?
I am still not sure EXACTLY which versions in 3.3.* raised an issue with one of our tests in `tests/test_plot.py`. Because of this, I am just changing the specification to not allow ANY version in 3.3.*, even though I think we could get more specific about what is actually broken. If anyone wants to investigate which versions are actually broken feel free. But for now, I think this is an improvement. 

I have tested 3.4.0 - 3.4.3 on my machine locally and tests passed.

issue.title: Update `matplotlib` version specification to only disallow `3.3.*`
issue.body:
- [ ] Does this PR add any new dependencies?
- [ ] Does this PR modify any existing APIs?
   - [ ] Is the change to the API backwards compatible?
- [ ] Have you built the documentation (reference and/or tutorial) and verified the generated documentation is appropriate?

#### Reference Issues/PRs
Closes #726 

#### What does this implement/fix? Briefly explain your changes.
Updates the version spec to allow most recent versions of matplotlib

#### Any other comments?
I am still not sure EXACTLY which versions in 3.3.* raised an issue with one of our tests in `tests/test_plot.py`. Because of this, I am just changing the specification to not allow ANY version in 3.3.*, even though I think we could get more specific about what is actually broken. If anyone wants to investigate which versions are actually broken feel free. But for now, I think this is an improvement. 

I have tested 3.4.0 - 3.4.3 on my machine locally and tests passed.
